intro: Antiphylla, commonly known as the mountain holly, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Ericaceae. It consists of several species native to mountainous regions of South America, particularly in Chile and Argentina. These plants are shrubs or small trees that typically grow in high-altitude environments with cool, moist climates. Antiphylla species are characterized by their evergreen leaves and small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. They play an important ecological role in their native habitats, providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
